#Text=The Moor of Rannoch A PICTURESQUE SOLITUDE In the course of an interesting article in the Pall Mall Gazette , Sir Herbert Maxwell says : There is no solitude known to me in the United Kingdom equal to the Moor of Rannoch for monotony and extent .
#Text=The black country of the midlands and the North is more depressing ; but , vast and drear as it is , there is no solitude there .
#Text=The Bog of Allen is as flat as Rannoch , but not so featureless , for a kindlier climate and lower elevation encourages strips of precarious cultivation .

#Text=The Monodh Lia , last refuge of the Scottish wolf , can hardly be beat for savage aspect , yet its ravines offer shelter from the storm ; whereas woe betide the traveller who would face a blizzard on Rannoch Moor .

#Text=It is a plateau of sodden peat , a thousand feet above sea level , eight and twenty miles from end to end , fifteen from side to side , broken only by miry channels and sullen tarns of unknown depth .
#Text=The Master of Ballantrae - teste( ?
#Text=) R.L.S. - managed to ride across it .
#Text=Felix opportunitate !
#Text=Such exploits are facile in romance , but never have I seen the midsummer when I would trust even a Highland pony to pick a footing through those inky moss hags .
#Text=The moor is no longer the absolute solitude it was a few years ago .

#Text=At rare intervals during the day a white ringlet appears on the horizon and creeps steadily across the vast brown expanse , showing where the West Highland Railway , not otherwise to be detected , traverses the wilderness .
#Text=Not a tree in sight , yet was this great plain once forest from end to end .
#Text=All along the railway cuttings and wherever the snow floods have rent the mantle of peat you may see the bones of the primaeval woodland - pine and birch lying as they fell one across another .
#Text=Why did they fall ?
#Text=or , rather , why when they had fallen , did the forest not renew itself by seed ?
#Text=Ah , that is one of the unsolved problems of our islands .
#Text=Not only here but far up the mountain sides , at altitudes which now will suffer no loftier growth than a reed shaken by the wind , the pines once grew tall and close .
#Text=If seed were shed there now it would rot ; if young trees were planted , they would never root themselves , so sour and wet is the soil .
#Text=The Romans felled the forest , say some wiseneres( ?
#Text=) ; the Norsemen burnt it , affirm others ; but neither hypothesis explains why new growth did not arise , as in the virgin forests of other lands .
#Text=More reasonably has the failure been traced to cosmic change - to alternating aeons of wet and dry .
#Text=The nobler growth postulate effective drainage ; when rain falls faster than it can run off , the soil becomes water-logged , sphagnum accumulates , and seedling trees are smothered .

#Text=They bid us take heart , these robust intellects for whom a thousand years is as one day , assuring us that we are past the worst and are ascending the dry grade ; but we are probably still some thousands of years short of the time when tree growth will prevail once more over strangling mosses and baser cryptogams .
#Text=Unspeakably cheerless , dangerously fierce as this moorland is on dark or stormy days , it has broad , kindly smiles for those who have patience to wait for them .

#Text=Sunlight , flooding it from end to end , extracts a subtle pungency from leagues of heather and bog myrtle , the air is full of the sound of gauzy wings , and every tarn vies with the others in depth of blue .
#Text=
